title: Sanford, Maine
text:
Sanford is a city in <a href="York%20County%2C%20Maine">York County</a>, <a href="Maine">Maine</a>, United States. The population was 21,982 in the <a href="2020%20United%20States%20Census">2020 census</a>, making it the seventh largest municipality in the state. Situated on the <a href="Mousam%20River">Mousam River</a>, Sanford includes the village of <a href="Springvale%2C%20Maine">Springvale</a>. The city features many lakes in wooded areas which attract campers.
Sanford is part of the <a href="Portland%2C%20Maine">Portland</a>–<a href="South%20Portland%2C%20Maine">South Portland</a>–<a href="Biddeford%2C%20Maine">Biddeford</a>, Maine <a href="Portland-South%20Portland-Biddeford%20metropolitan%20area">metropolitan statistical area</a>.
On November 6, 2012, Sanford voters approved a new charter to re-incorporate Sanford as a city and replace the town meeting format with a city council/mayor/strong manager form of government, along with other changes. The new charter took effect on January 1, 2013. Sanford's new charter provides that the first mayor would be appointed from the ranks of Sanford's seven city councilors and serve interim for one-year period. On January 8, 2013, Maura A. Herlihy was appointed as Sanford's first mayor.
In 2014, an elected-at-large mayor took office. On November 5, 2013, Thomas Cote was elected as mayor. Beginning in 2016, the mayoral position began being elected at-large every two years during legislative election cycles.
History.
Sanford is in the western portion of a tract of land purchased in 1661 from <a href="Abenaki">Abenaki</a> Chief Fluellin by Major William Phillips, an owner of mills in <a href="Saco%2C%20Maine">Saco</a>. First called Phillipstown, it was willed in 1696 by Mrs. Phillips to her former husband's son, Peleg Sanford. Settlement was delayed, however, by hostilities during the <a href="French%20and%20Indian%20Wars">French and Indian Wars</a>. In 1724, <a href="Norridgewock">Norridgewock</a>, a Native <a href="fortification">stronghold</a> on the <a href="Kennebec%20River">Kennebec River</a>, was destroyed by a <a href="Province%20of%20Massachusetts%20Bay">Massachusetts</a> <a href="militia">militia</a>. Subsequently, the region became less dangerous, and Sanford was first settled in 1739. Incorporated a town in 1768, it was named after Peleg Sanford. Until 1794, <a href="Alfred%2C%20Maine">Alfred</a> was the town's North <a href="Parish">Parish</a>.
The Mousam River provided <a href="water%20power">water power</a> for industry. In 1745, Capt. Market Morrison built a <a href="sawmill">sawmill</a> above <a href="Springvale%2C%20Maine">Springvale</a>. Following the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">Civil War</a>, Sanford developed into a <a href="textile">textile</a> manufacturing center, connected to markets by the <a href="Portland%20and%20Rochester%20Railroad">Portland and Rochester Railroad</a>. Factories were built at both Springvale and Sanford villages. Products included <a href="cotton">cotton</a> and <a href="woolen">woolen</a> goods, carpets, <a href="shoemaking">shoes</a> and <a href="lumber">lumber</a>.
In 1867, British-born Thomas Goodall established the <a href="Goodall%20Mills">Goodall Mills</a> at Sanford, after selling another mill in 1865 at <a href="Troy%2C%20New%20Hampshire">Troy, New Hampshire</a> which made woolen blankets contoured to fit horses. His factory beside the Mousam River first manufactured <a href="carriage">carriage</a> robes and <a href="blanket">blanket</a>s. It would expand to make <a href="mohair">mohair</a> plush for upholstering <a href="railroad">railroad</a> seats, carpets, draperies, auto fabrics, military uniform fabric and Palm Beach fabric for summer suits.
The company's textiles were known for brilliant and fast colors and found buyers worldwide. From 1880 to 1910, the <a href="mill%20town">mill town's</a> population swelled from 2,700 to over 9,000, some living in houses built by the company and sold to workers at cost. In 1914, the Goodall family built Goodall Park, a 784-seat roofed <a href="stadium">stadium</a>, now a treasured historic site. They also helped build the library, town hall, hospital, airport, and golf club. A <a href="bronze">bronze</a> statue was erected by the citizens of Sanford in 1917 to the memory of Thomas Goodall. His effigy has a place of honor in Central Park. George and Henrietta Goodall's daughter, <a href="Marion%20C.%20Goodall">Marion C. Goodall</a> Marland, and her husband William Marland continued the Goodall family philanthropy. A dormitory at Nasson College bears the Marland's name.
In 1954, <a href="Burlington%20Industries">Burlington Mills</a>, then the nation's largest textile firm, bought <a href="Sanford%20Mills">Sanford Mills</a>. After moving the <a href="loom">loom</a>s to its <a href="Southern%20United%20States">Southern</a> plants, Burlington closed Sanford Mills—leaving 3,600 unemployed and of empty mills. Local business owners began traveling the northeast, enticing employers to move to the area. In November 1955, NBC's <a href="Armstrong%20Circle%20Theatre">Armstrong Circle Theatre</a> dramatized Sanford's comeback on television in “The Town that Refused to Die”, starring <a href="Darren%20McGavin">Darren McGavin</a> and <a href="Jason%20Robards">Jason Robards</a>. The story was later featured in <a href="Life%20Magazine">"LIFE"</a> magazine's feature on "Community Boosters" on August 5, 1957. It now has diversified industries, including manufacturing and biotech. When the federal government offered money in the 1960s for <a href="urban%20renewal">urban renewal</a> to rehabilitate aging or blighted districts, more than thirty Sanford structures were razed. In Springvale, three of four corners were leveled. Nevertheless, much fine <a href="architecture">architecture</a> from the town's prosperous mill era survived.
Sanford was the home of Belle Ashton Leavitt, the third woman attorney admitted to the Maine Bar Association. Leavitt was admitted to the Bar in 1900. Leavitt operated in partnership with attorney Fred J. Allen, her brother-in-law (Allen was married to Belle's sister Ida Leavitt), and member of the <a href="Maine%20Legislature">Maine Legislature</a>.
The town gained national notoriety in 1984, when Scott Waterhouse, then age 18, strangled 12-year-old Gycelle Cote. Rumors of <a href="Satanism">Satanism</a> surrounded the case, and some of Waterhouse's personal belongings were deemed to be occult in nature. These included a copy of "<a href="The%20Satanic%20Bible">The Satanic Bible</a>" and a notebook carrying Satanic drawings and poetry. The furor culminated in several tabloid stories, national television coverage, and at least one headline referring to the town as "Terrortown!".
The town again gained national notoriety on November 9, 2009, when the Amber Alert system was first used in the state for 2-year-old Hailey Traynham, abducted by her father.
In 2003, Maine voters rejected a proposal to build a $650 million <a href="casino">casino</a> in <a href="South%20Sanford%2C%20Maine">South Sanford</a>. The development, ostensibly owned by the <a href="Penobscot%20people">Penobscot</a> and <a href="Passamaquoddy">Passamaquoddy</a> nations, would have included 4,000 <a href="slot%20machine">slot machine</a>s, 180 gaming tables, a hotel, a <a href="convention%20center">convention center</a> and an 18-hole <a href="golf%20course">golf course</a>. Proponents argued it would add 4,700 permanent jobs and direct 25% of its revenue to the state. Detractors predicted higher crime, traffic and an erosion of Maine's quality of life.
On June 23, 2017, the largest mill fire Sanford firefighters have ever battled erupted. The flaming five-story back building of the former Stenton Trust Mill complex at 13 River Street brought more than 100 firefighters from 20 communities to battle the blaze. The complex, which was built in 1922 as a <a href="textile%20mill">textile mill</a>, includes two five-story brick and concrete buildings and a one-story connecting structure. Two days later, three boys from Sanford, two 13-year-olds and a 12-year-old, were charged with felony arson in connection with the fire. They pleaded guilty to criminal mischief and were placed on probation for a year.
Geography.
Sanford is located at (43.439925, -70.773304).
According to the <a href="United%20States%20Census%20Bureau">United States Census Bureau</a>, the city has a total area of , of which, of it is land and is water. Located near <a href="foothill">foothill</a>s, Sanford is drained by the Mousam River. Mt. Hope, elevation 680 feet (207 m) above sea level, is the city's highest point. The lowest elevation, which is approximately 140 feet (42.7 m) above sea level, is on the Mousam River at Old Falls Pond as it flows into Kennebunk.
Sanford borders the towns of <a href="Shapleigh">Shapleigh</a>, <a href="Acton%2C%20Maine">Acton</a>, <a href="Alfred%2C%20Maine">Alfred</a>, <a href="Kennebunk%2C%20Maine">Kennebunk</a>, <a href="Wells%2C%20Maine">Wells</a>, <a href="North%20Berwick%2C%20Maine">North Berwick</a>, and <a href="Lebanon%2C%20Maine">Lebanon</a>.
Climate.
The climate is <a href="humid%20continental">humid continental</a>, similar to nearby towns such as Concord, New Hampshire. The <a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20climate%20classification">Köppen</a> is "Dfb".
Demographics.
2010 census.
As of the <a href="census">census</a> of 2010, 20,798 people, 8,500 households, and 5,417 families resided in the city. The <a href="population%20density">population density</a> was . There were 9,452 housing units at an average density of . The city's racial makeup was 94.7% <a href="White%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">White</a>, 0.6% <a href="African%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">African American</a>, 0.4% <a href="Native%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Native American</a>, 2.0% <a href="Asian%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Asian</a>, 0.3% from <a href="Race%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">other races</a>, and 2.0% from two or more races. <a href="Hispanic%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Hispanic</a> or <a href="Latino%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Latino</a> of any race made up 1.6% of the population.
There were 8,500 households, of which 30.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 44.7% were <a href="Marriage">married couples</a> living together, 13.1% had a female householder with no husband present, 5.9% had a male householder with no wife present, and 36.3% were non-families. 28.9% of all households were made up of individuals, and 11.2% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.41 and the average family size was 2.91.
The median age in the city was 40.5 years. 22.6% of residents were under the age of 18; 8.2% were between the ages of 18 and 24; 25% were from 25 to 44; 29% were from 45 to 64, and 15.1% were 65 years of age or older. The gender makeup of the city was 47.9% male and 52.1% female.
2000 census.
As of the <a href="census">census</a> of 2000, there were 20,806 people, 8,270 households, and 5,449 families residing in the CDP. The <a href="population%20density">population density</a> was 435.3 people per square mile (168.1/km). There were 8,807 housing units at an average density of 184.3 per square mile (71.1/km). The racial makeup of the CDP was 95.68% <a href="White%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">White</a>, 0.44% <a href="African%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Black</a> or <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">African American</a>, 0.31% <a href="Native%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Native American</a>, 2.07% <a href="Asian%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Asian</a>, 0.02% <a href="Pacific%20Islander%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Pacific Islander</a>, 0.27% from <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">other races</a>, and 1.21% from two or more races. <a href="Hispanic%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Hispanic</a> or <a href="Latino%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Latino</a> of any race were 0.96% of the population.
There were 8,270 households, out of which 33.7% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 48.5% were <a href="Marriage">married couples</a> living together, 12.7% had a female householder with no husband present, and 34.1% were non-families. 27.6% of all households were made up of individuals, and 11.7% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.48 and the average family size was 3.01.
In the CDP the population was spread out, with 26.7% under the age of 18, 8.1% from 18 to 24, 29.0% from 25 to 44, 21.8% from 45 to 64, and 14.4% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 37 years. For every 100 females, there were 93.5 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 90.0 males.
The median income for a household in the CDP was $34,668, and the median income for a family was $43,021. Males had a median income of $33,115 versus $24,264 for females. The <a href="per%20capita%20income">per capita income</a> for the CDP was $16,951. About 11.1% of families and 12.8% of the overall population were below the <a href="poverty%20line">poverty line</a>, including 17.0% of those under age 18 and 11.2% of those aged 65 or over.
Voter registration
Fire Department.
Sanford citizens are protected by Firefighter/EMT's working out of three fire stations located in Springvale, South Sanford, and Downtown Sanford. 3 Engines, 1 Ladder, and 1 Rescue are staffed 24 hours a day; 365 days a year. Authorized strength is 45 full-time fire personnel. SFD also provides Emergency Medical Services. All firefighters are required to have a Maine EMS license ranging from EMT-Basic to Paramedic. In 2007 SFD responded to 1,150 Fire Runs & 2,515 Medical Runs for a total of 3,665 emergencies.
School system.
In 2018, Hutter Construction Co. workers built a new high school on a 127-acre campus in the center of town. The construction cost was billed at $103 million, with the state covering the majority of the cost. It is a career-focused school, separated into four wings, in which students select specialized courses geared towards their preferred future career.
